transcripts.text: Hey, I haven't heard from you in like a week.  We were getting a little worried there.  Are you guys okay in Morocco?  What's going on?

Yeah, so we've been really busy.  It's actually pretty hard to get phone service out here.  So where to start?  Look, it's massive.  I won't lie, I'm pretty excited.  I can imagine.  There's a large-scale human trafficking organization here.  I know police intelligence here, they're actually having a crackdown on it at the moment.  But we've managed to get ourselves an interview, a frontline interview with one of the guys who actually traffics people.  So place them in a boat, puts them on a boat to Spain.  This guy's name, it's been pretty hard to get the interview, but he's agreed to do a video interview for us.
He's agreed to be on video.  That is insane.

There's a couple of issues here in Morocco, though.  I'm sure you're aware, but filming is really restrictive legally here.  It's pretty crazy.  There's checkpoints everywhere.  So bring the bare essentials that you can to get this done.  We'll break the cameras down.  We'll just put them in various compartments in the car.  There is some real ramifications if we do get caught.  There has been journalists jailed here and I think the fines are pretty huge and there could be some real jail time around that.  But we do need to jump on this quickly in the next couple of days.

I'm booking tickets right now and I should be seeing you either tonight or first thing in the morning.  This is huge.  Okay, so we just got back from investigating and talking to some people at a little migrant holdout here in the mountains out of Ecuador, a little town on the coast of Morocco, right across from Spain, where tons of migrants from sub-Saharan
Africa are

just sitting here waiting for their chance to get on a little dinghy raft to go over to Spain.  And it's been hours.  We've been waiting all day.  And our guy hasn't shown up.  He's nowhere to be found.  He's sending us Really brief messages.  Yes, no, back and forth.  He's super nervous about talking to us.  But I'm just going to kind of hold out here and see.  Because if we could talk to him and really figure out what's going on here, that would be huge.  So it's getting dark soon.  Probably going to have to interview him in the dark if he does show up.  My name is .

I'm 20 years old.  I spent eight months here.  How do people get to Spain?  People have to spend a lot of money here.  They have to spend 2,000 euro, 4,000 euro or 2,500 euro.  You have to spend 2,500 dirham.  Well, in Nador, it's 2,000 euro.
Euro.  Why is it more expensive here?  Longer distance?
2,500 dirham is 250 euro.
Wow, from 10 years.
But it's not guaranteed.  When you enter in a span, you are lucky.  When you don't enter, you have lost the money.  You try again to have another money to go.  Right.
And how do you guarantee in Nador?

When you are in the boat here, in Nador, You go to the other zone.  They say the international zone.  You are in Spain.  After you have one birth, they call it salvamento.  Salvamento is the Spanish name.  Salva.  Salva is to save you.  Salva.  To save you in the moment.  They come, they pick the person, and they go in Spain.
How much money can you make per boat from the door to Spain?

Well, you know, every person, you can have 2,000, 2,500, 4,000.  You have the totality.  50 person, you have to calculate.  50 person, you do 50 person.  Everybody, everybody, 2,500, 2,500.  When the boat enter, the boss have a lot of money.  But in this morning, The Moroccan man have him money.
Who is the Moroccan man?

The Moroccan man, the customer don't know it.  Only the boss will know it.  When you have to go to Spain, they take me, go to the beach, they enter to the boat, we go.  It's a business.  No black man can go, cannot go to Spain.  If you are not, if it's not business, if it's not business, you cannot go to Spain.
How many people are sent over to Spain from here?  a week or a month?

A week you can have, one day you can have 500 person.  One day you can have 500 persons, but the month you can have 2,000.  Or when you have a lot of security, in the whole of the weekend you can have 100, 200.  But when the security is so easy, you can have the day 500 persons.
Do you get your money back if the boat doesn't make it?

Yeah, you get your money back.  When you do it, guarantee.  But when you give... When you give the money in your boss, he can say, when you touch the water, you lose it.  But when you do it, guarantee, if you don't enter, the money is your money.
So you can pay more for a guarantee?

Yeah, where the guarantee, you have one bank, you go there, you put your money there, you have the court.  The court is your court.  When you enter, you call, you call your boss, take the court.  After the boss take the court, go to the bank and receive the money.
How do you help the boss?

The other person, you can call your brother in Senegal.  You say, if you want to go in Spain, I have my brother here.  He can help you to go to Spain.  He'll ask me how much.  I give him the price.  2,500 euro, 2,000 euro, 4,000 euro.  When he come, he give me 4,000 euro.  I can give the boss.  Or when you go to the bank of Guantanamo, I do there 2,500 euro.  The rest, I put it money.  It's for me.
Are you helping any friends go to Spain now?
Yeah, I have to have two brothers.  I meet them in Tangier, two brothers.  They're going to Spain.
They're in Spain now?
Yeah, they're in Spain now.  Why don't people legally apply?
Why don't people try to go in legally?
Because in our country, it's so difficult to have a visa.  It's so difficult to have a visa.  When you have money to give the government, when I...
Is it okay?
Stop there.

So our guy is just one off.  We just had a local farmer pull up and the car coming out into this field with the light on.  Thought it was a sting operation, I guess.  They're so worried that we're working with the cops.  We're trying to set them up.  We're trying to get them arrested.  And we just sprinted into the woods.  And he's got a laugh mic.  He's gone.  There's a good chance he's not going to come back.  He's going to think that this is all a setup.  We're going to lose and burn all of our contacts in this area.  We've been cultivating contacts for a week here, paying guys to talk to these people.  And now they're going to think we're cops because of a farmer.  I guess we could wait around and hope he comes back.
